summary: OF AN AGE is set in the summer of 1999 as a 17-year-old Serbian born, Australian amateur ballroom dancer experiences an unexpected and intense 24-hour romance with a friend's older brother.

reviews.content: Not many movies make me cry. This one really touched me.

This is one of those movies that sticks with you for days after you see it. The pacing, while torturous, was absolutely perfect for the story. The pace felt like another character of the story, and was absolutely necessary to dive into the soul of the characters. The performances were sublime. I felt such an ache for the characters at the end of the movie. Really breathtaking on every level.
Absolutely fantastic story!

The most beautiful film on first/true love and coming of age. The script and the rhythm of the movie was as beautiful and romantic as the music of the film which was so eloquently picked. Just so beyond beautifully made.

Driven by natural dialogue and conversations that put you directly into the mindsets of these characters. Even the tight close-ups in the 4:3 aspect ratio drive you deeper into their heads. Simple, sweet, and sad all at the same time. Have you too, also ever experienced, one of those perfect chemistry pairings where you are doomed to live separate lives? Will you too also constantly look back and think "what if?"

Of An Age is an indelibly great Australian film, a film of great tenderness, understanding and compassion. Written and directed by Goran Stolevski, it's a film informed by his growing up gay and Serbian in Melbourne. The film is set in two time periods, each one taking place in only a handful of days. The first period is 1999. High schooler Ebony has woken up drunk on a beach after a big night out. She calls her friend and dance partner Kol to help and pick her up. He enlists the help of her older brother Adam to drive across the city to find her. The thirty minute or so conversation in the car is a near perfect scene of conversation and understanding, just beautifully observed. We discover eventually that Adam is gay and that Kol more than likely is, something he hides from his conservative Serbian family. Over the next day they get to know each better. Fast forward to 2010 and both men are returning to Melbourne to attend Ebony's wedding. We then find out where their lives have taken them. The wedding is the perfect place to go visit regrets and misfortune. This is a beautiful film. So tender and honest. A film about knowing yourself and showing yourself. A film about relationships and missed opportunities. Thom Green and Elias Anton are wonderful in the lead roles. A small Australian classic.

beautiful movie
made me cry and laugh

Absolutely beautiful film! Saw it in theaters and balled my eyes out. I'm not a big movie rewatcher, but as soon as I left the theater I knew I wanted to see it again and I did. Easily in my top 5 movies.
Profoundly moving Australian love story set over a day in 1999 in Melbourne and then 11 years later. The cast were outstanding! It had heart, humour and angst that we can all relate to.
This was awesome!!!!

Moderately enjoyable if fairly routine, familiar comedy romance.  Cast is spirited and efficient (especially Julia Harari).  Time-jump in the last 1/3 was mishandled, setting up a weak ending.  Bright dialogue is diluted by the thick-accented slang-heavy exchanges which are often hard to follow, making it likely to be better enjoyed on video with subtitles (just sayin'!).
Loved the story of realistic emotion. Not about sex, its about LOVE.
Amazing and beautiful
This is a lovely film about love and youth and those defining moments that help to make us who we grow into as adults.
This was a really good coming of age/coming out movie. It was very well acted and I likede the story
I enjoyed this overall, but it needed subtitles. I couldn't understand a lot of the dialogue, especially the phone booth scene at the beginning. She may as well have been speaking a foreign language.

"Of An Age" is the story of a burgeoning relationship between two men, but it's not an in-your-face political statement about gay relationships.  In fact, because of the film's intense focus on that moment of total infatuation where only two people exist in the world, gender is almost incidental.
Macedonian-born Aussie Writer/Director Goren Stolevski's second film centers on a single day in 1999 when Adam (Thom Green) and Kol (Elias Anton) meet.  Kol receives a frantic call from his ballroom dance partner Ebony.  She's slept off the consequences of a long night on an unknown beach.  The only way Kol can retrieve her and make the Dance Finals is to beg Ebony's brother, Adam, for a ride.  While traveling in a car together, Kol and Adam start with banter and a tentative discussion of literature and philosophy.  But the conversation and the sense of connection quickly turn into something much deeper.
Adam and Kol are both charismatic and appealing.  Anton is an awkward seventeen, enthralled by the mature man who's at least four years older and much more worldly-wise.  While Kol is still struggling with defining himself in a conservative household of Macedonian emigrants, Adam seems to have it all figured out.  In fact, Adam is leaving the next day to begin his graduate studies in South America.  So theirs is a relationship killed by circumstance before it can ever develop.
A brief Act Two reintroduces the two characters in 2010 at Ebony's wedding.  It's a powerful postscript to their earlier encounter.  While incidentally noting that the world has changed dramatically in the intervening eleven years, there's a painful wistfulness shared by Kol and Adam that's simply heartbreaking.
Cinematographer Matthew Chuang ("Blue Bayou") uses an in-your-face camera technique that inserts us into the thoughts and feelings of these appealing characters.  At times, however, the sense of intimacy and immediacy feels almost claustrophobic.
What's missing here is actual character development.  While the sense of connection between Adam and Kol is extremely powerful, the story suffers because they are such obvious stereotypes.  Adam is older, wiser and more jaded.  In many ways, we understand Kol solely in terms of his confusion, awkwardness and naiveté.  This reduces the emotional impact of the film, though only slightly.
At the end of the day, this is a film with universal appeal.  Everyone will recognize the tension, exhilaration and obsession of first love.  Some will leave the theater grieving that they did not end up with the love of their lives.  The rest of us will walk away with an even deeper appreciation for what we have.
Beautiful movie, deeply emotional story, great acting, electric chemistry

Taking this movie in the context of a low budget production and knowing what their other films are like, I thought it was alright. It has a few unrealistic plot holes but tells a story about a closeted gay dancer who wastes much of his life hiding from himself. Spoiler Alert: it doesn't come to a definitive conclusion so if making up an ending isn't your thing this might not be the film for you.

The movie was quite all over the place, I see other peoples reviews and critiques. I'm not quite sure I understand them completely.

The acting is OK, minus the female lead, she is all over the place ridiculous with her acting, and I believe it's the script that made it so terrible, to watch her on the screen.

The two lead males, do not have real chemistry or connection like they should, and the emotions you do not get the emotions from the film like you should. The intimacy scene is just not even intimate. It's kind of there and done. So the entire thing is very confusing. I thought I was going to get a story about these individuals, but I ended up getting a fake love story. 

Ultimately, the movie is more of a streaming film instead of a theatrical release, but at the end of the day, it's also one of those films that you can just go never mind I don't need to add that to my watchlist. I don't recommend it to be honest with you.
Great characters in a heartbreaking story. Leads have fantastic chemistry and a a believable connection. Cinematography gives an almost claustrophobic intimacy.
Very good bringing the characters close to full circle…. But I wish Adam and Kol had more closure. Overall well written and well acted. Kol’s glowup was amazing!!!
Absolutely amazing, so glad I got to see this in a theater because it really deserves it!
First rate movie, Romantic and realistic!

This was a solid romantic discovery movie with solid acting and good on screen chemistry. The weird thing about it was it felt both too long and too short at the same time based on how the movie was done.

Good old fashioned acting.  No computer graphics and no explosions (well one) but just really smoke.  Just good acting. Very refreshing when computer graphics dont take over the movies and actors and actresses actually have to act.  Well made movie. Ending was odd  but, it is what it is.
The story is told with a lot of sensibility. Actors play very well specifically the main character Kol. I love the movie.
live like no other, in order to live like no other - Dave Ramsey
very romantic 😍 love story
Needed captions. Needed skin care for the actors. Needed the camera to pull back. Story… meh. Ending… unsatisfying. I saw it for free and paid too much!
I would not even watch a movie like that!
Heartbreaking and beautiful.
It's emotional, heartbreaking and lovely.

Frustratingly inaudible/unintelligible dialog throughout. I sort of wanted  to know what they were saying, but also knew that it wasn’t very profound. Slightly interesting contrast between their lives in 1999 and 2010. Got a thing for close-ups of bad skin?  THIS IS YOUR MOVIE!
Great believable acting, slightly disjointed story line. I felt  cheated with the ending but that may have been the intention of the writer.
A basic but somewhat realistic love story but the plit was slow and flat at times.

The talented cast couldn't do much with such a lineal one-note script. The unnecessary long scenes telegraph every emotion and thought the characters are experiencing, making the film dull. The camera work was the worst, with extreme close-ups that just highlight the apparent intentions of the actors. I want my two hours back.
Film was a bit on the slow side. Was heartfelt and intimate. Ending wasn't satisfying but I would say a good movie.
A nice independent film, glad I was able to see it on the big screen. Thom Green and Elias Anton were great together.

Although the movie was slow moving, that fit with the story line. It was quite moving. It was hard to understand some of it, particularly the main female character when she was practically hysterical in the beginning.
Excellent emotional story and movie.

Rotten tomatoes needs to lay off calling this a "queer love story". It's just a love story. With that being said, I thought the film was beautifully executed & acted, however the ending was a bit unsatisfactory & abrupt. A good watch nonetheless.

While I would say that "Of an Age" is easily comparable to similar and better movies, it is still a solid addition. This movie works because of the characters and their genuine interactions. I found myself finding the humor in some moments and feeling the pain in others, which is a feat considering this movie isn't really meant for my demographic. I think it is technically well made and full of rich conversations that allowed me as a viewer to learn more about these characters and get a glimpse into their world. While I feel like the movie could have explored even more and felt a bit on the simple and safe side, I still think it is a good intimate story with great performances. Overall, this is a movie that is similar to others that I won't get into naming here, but it also does just enough to have a unique voice of its own and is worth checking out.

This was such a powerful story that revolves around such an intense bond between Adam and Kol. Many LGBTQ+ people I know have their own version of "Adam", someone that helped them see that it is ok to be yourself and perhaps give you a sense of security for the first time. It has been 24 hours since I watched the movie and I can't stop thinking about and relating to this movie.

For starters, I didn't understand half the dialogue. Australian accents, soft-spoken, mumbled. 
The first 10 minutes are screaming drama(!).
Story goes essentially nowhere.
Jumpy camera work. Lots of close-ups where no one says or does anything.
Inexplicable circumstances. 
Spoiler alert -- they have a one-night stand, one leaves (this was pre-planned, so not like a surprise), don't see each other for 10 years. Then one is upset that the other got married. Really?
Waste my time.
Thoughtful story, marred by crazy wobbly camera work and generally unintelligible dialogue. Very heavy Australian accents were difficult to understand.
Camera closeness was nauseating.
incredible & nuanced & beautiful & real
So well done, beautifully shot and extremely emotional. The acting was phenomenal and the ending scene was palpable. I was completely taken by surprise how fantastic this was.

Photography -  Shaky , too many loooong close up face scenes  . Audio - difficult to unscramble lines  due to accent and background music . Don't know if any of the 20+ lines I  missed were important but I won't watch  it again to find out . 
The Story was good , movie not so much .

Dull and plodding, the film is shot in a standard format, with 90% of the screen time spent in close-ups, sometimes you are not sure who is speaking.  By the time the second act comes along you're left wondering, what in the world is going on and when we get to the end, you're left thinking what the hell happened?  None of the characters have any believability, obviously, this "art" film is nothing but uninteresting and unbelievable.
The end leaves you wanting more. Best hook possible when a movie is leaving you thinking about what happened next in their story.
This film had me feeling seen and understood. It brought back memories of my youth and my understanding of love back then. I loved it!
I was told to see this movie.  I wouldn't go to the movies to see this. I would watch it at home in two parts.
Very strong performances. Would have liked to have seen a more restrained use of facial closeups on the part of the director.
This film is feels very authentic. Draws you in and keeps you engaged. Well worth the visit to the theater

Distressingly close close-ups throughout. I'm Australian and even I had trouble understanding all the dialogue - those around me, with American ears, missed a lot. Thoughtful movie but sad. The first scene should have been revisited at the end of the movie when we had more context for it?

The natural side of my brain feels sad. My good friend, who met his match when he was young can’t have babies. Doesn’t want to adopt, but looks at all the other guys who have had kids and he has a ton of money, no blood to pass it down to. This started when their mothers are too strong and impressionable. Same old story every time when you see past the art.
Absolutely fantastic. Hands down must see
A wonderful and touching love story.

Incredibly moving story that takes you back to that age. Beautifully written and one of the best jobs I've ever seen of making the gap in the story of 11 years look believable. It actually looks like it was filmed in two parts over a period of years.

"| Ratings Categories |
{Characters (9/10) ; Cinematography (9/10) ; Plot (9.5/10) ; Acting (9/10) ; Pacing (8.5/10) = 90%}"
Beautifully shot, poignant pacing and incredible acting

I'm a 73 year old heterosexual woman, and this is a love story, not a gay love story. The authenticity, the quality of the acting, the sensitivity, all make it one of the best movies I've ever seen. It just felt so real, and this is a world I know nothing about, except that love is universal, and people are the same everywhere. Everything about the film was outstanding. I'm really grateful I had a chance to see it.
I LOVED IT! The direction, acting, photography was all first rate. I got really into this movie. It makes me want to know more about the characters.

"Of An Age" is a mix between two other LGBT films "Moonlight," and "Weekend." It is an indie film I feel has been done before, but the ending was fulfilling enough to leave a pleasant feeling in my heart as I left the theatre.
Any gay man who went though the closet period with unaccepting family will understand the dynamics of romance in this movie
Beautiful, heartbreaking movie.
Well done to the entire cast & beautifully shot.

This film exists in the thin line between comedy and tragedy, a slice of life at two critical moments of Kol’s story that while narratively is very particular to it’s time and space, holds a universal application of exploration, acceptance, love and ultimately being at peace with the choices we make and those we had no say in, sometimes we carry a single moment forever and even the briefest chance to revisit it, while heartbreaking, holds a sweet catharsis.

Beautifully written. Endearing, sweet & heartbreaking. I was surprised by the twist & was not put off by the way it concluded. It most certainly left me wondering. My heart wanted to know more than my mind. Love is not always logical.
Emotional,  brilliant acting, heartbreaking....fabulous cinimatography...
Such a good story line. Perfect for my sappy heart
Definitely another gay coming-of-age movie, but, it was well-acted and casted. The soundtrack (especially at the wedding) was good!
Beautiful and very touching move, with incredible performance by the two main actors.
Sweet and tender, surprising. Not always easy to understand the dialogue ( to this American ear), but no matter, the story is clear.

loved it. a beautiful story and very moving.  the two actors were amazing.  the makeup was remarkable to take the main character from adolescence to adulthood. I loved Elias Anton, an incredible actor who gave a superb performance.
One of the best coming of age stories I've seen in a long time. So aching and emotionally transporting - I'm still thinking about it days later. Sweet and sad and beautiful.

I don’t understand the positive reviews of this. Just an awful awful movie. We walked out after 60 minutes. Nothing happens!!! Boring, poor character development, shot mostly in closeups in a car :(. Zzzzzzzzzzzzzz
